awd_titl_txt: Topology of Kaehler Manifolds, Surface Bundles, and Outer Automorphism Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
The main subject of this project is geometric group theory. One of the guiding principles behind geometric group theory, as developed by Klein and more recently Gromov, is that one can understand a geometric object by studying its symmetries. The primary goal of this project is to utilize techniques from geometric group theory as a bridge to simplify and solve problems in other fields of mathematics. The first part of this project focuses on algebraic varieties, which are geometric spaces defined by polynomial equations. Algebraic varieties arise naturally in a wide-range of disciplines, including high-energy physics and cryptography. Although these objects have been studied for centuries, many of their geometric properties still remain unknown, and cannot be uncovered using traditional means. The PI proposes novel geometric group theory methods to develop restrictions on properties of algebraic varieties. The second part of this project studies the symmetries of right-angled Artin groups, which have important connections to low-dimensional topology, as well as robotics, phylogenetic trees, and computer science. In addition, the PI will advise undergraduate mathematics majors and mentor graduate students through organizing seminars and other mathematical activities.

The study of mapping class groups and the moduli space of curves lies at the intersection of algebraic geometry, Riemannian geometry, and topology.  The first part of this project studies the topology of surface and torus bundles admitting some extra structure such as a Kaehler metric, or which are formal in the sense of rational homotopy theory.  The PI proposes techniques from geometric group theory and mapping class groups that can place restrictions on the fundamental group and monodromy of such bundles, but also connect questions about the geometry of complex projective surfaces to questions about mapping class groups. The second part of this project studies the automorphism groups of right-angled Artin groups (RAAGs), which comprise a large class of groups extending both free and free abelian groups. There is a fruitful analogy between the study of mapping class groups of surfaces, outer automorphism groups of free groups, and lattices in semisimple Lie groups. The role played by Teichmuller space, Culler-Vogtmann outer space, and symmetric spaces, respectively, is of fundamental importance in proving many key results about these groups. The PI proposes an analogous space for outer automorphisms of RAAGs, to provide a unified framework for studying automorphisms of free and free abelian groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Project sought to understand symmetries of geometric spaces admitting  special types of geometric structures. The second half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st saw an explosion of algebraic tools that can be used to study geometric spaces.  Although these tools are quite powerful, there are still many unanswered questions.  Part of this project was aimed at a concrete application of these tools in a very specific scenario, namely 4-dimensional spaces that locally look like a product of two 2-dimensional spaces. The specific spaces we consider arise in a number of natural settings throughout mathematics and physics.  We conjectured that the topology of some of these spaces (which are locally unions of tori) are controlled by very specific numerical invariants. These spaces are also endowed with a complex structure, which makes them particularly rigid. In joint work with Groves and Zhu (Algebraic and Geometric Topology, 2024), we succeeded in showing that many of these spaces do not admit certain types of geometric actions, enhancing previous results of Gromov and Delzant.

Instead of focusing on individual examples, the second main theme of this project took a more global approach. We studied spaces called cube complexes that are built out of cubes of various dimensions, with certain restrictions. It turns out that such spaces arise in a number of interesting settings in mathematics. Associated to these geometric spaces are algebraic objects called right-angled Artin groups (RAAGs).  These groups are symmetrized versions of a class of languages in which certain specified letters are allowed to commute with each other. These languages and spaces have connections to computer science via database algorithms, and the spaces themselves find numerous applications in robotics.  The main goal, roughly speaking, was to parametrize all cube complexes which are associated to the same RAAG.  In joint work with Charney and Vogtmann (Duke Mathematics Journal, 2023 & SMF 24: Geometric Methods in Group Theory, 2024) We succeeded in doing this, producing an "Outer Space" of such geometric objects . The advantage of having such a space is that it allows one to see the symmetries of the RAAG as a whole, whereas no one of the geometric structures will capture all of them.  However, it is expected that finite order symmetries are captured by individual examples.  In a follow-up paper (Algebraic and Geometric Topology, 2024), we have shown that each finite collection of symmetries is realized as a group of distance-preserving self-maps of a particular cube complex. There are still many new directions to explore, and we expect that the construction of outer space is merely the first step in the study of the symmetries of RAAGs. We hope it will lead to many more applications of our work.  

As part of the broader impacts this project, in the summer of 2023 we advised an undergraduate at the University of Southern Maine, a primarily undergraduate institution, on a project related to certain groups of upper triangular matrices.  The project was computational in nature, and the undergraduate, with my guidance, succeeded in developing an algorithm to calculate certain algebraic invariants associated to such collections of matrices.  Although the algorithm is relatively straightforward, there were no existing libraries allowing one to compute this invariant and there is still much to be accomplished in the way of optimization. Future investigations can use this code as a starting point. Moreover, the undergraduate became very interested in optimization problems as a result of the project, and is currently pursuing a PhD in Applied Mathematics at Tufts University.
